albums.title: Rust in Peace
albums.review: This album is one of the single best albums, in my opinion, of all time. Every song from start to finish is engineered exquisitely; it's splattered with melodic solos and furiously complex riffage, from Dave Mustaine and Marty Friedman. This, along with a combination of tight drums and spirally bass allows for a true masterpiece.

albums.title: Two
albums.review: After not really exploring much outside of metal, I was introduced to this album. This album combines attidue, dispair and resentment into a trio of anti-statist societal anger. Far from the one-dimensional teenage angst seen in some areas of hardcore and punk, this album looks deeply into cultural injustuice and demonstates it with abrasive vocals, pounding drums and droning guitars.

albums.title: The Oncoming Storm
albums.review: Straight from the New England metalcore scene, the The Oncoming Storm features a musical dichotomy of melodic, beautifully-harmonised guitars, with harsh, aggressive vocals. The sheer technical ability presented from Ken Susi and Buz McGrath lifts this LP up another step.

albums.title: Ashes of the Wake
albums.review: Seemingly evasive from any singular metal subgenre, Ashes of the Wake displays rhythmic guitars, raging vocals, and tight, filled drums. From the tremolo picking, to the guest solos played by Alex Skolnick and Chris Poland, everything about this album is perfect.
